items.title: Australia rings in 2026 with sombre commemoration, rainy fireworks
items.description: From sombre commemoration to thunderstruck fireworks, people gathered around Australia to welcome in 2026.

items.title: Efforts to mitigate 'homegrown' extremism revealed in cabinet documents
items.description: From expectations of a trade union backlash against controversial industrial relations reform, to concerns about "homegrown" extremism in Australia, here are what previously unseen cabinet documents tell us about Australian politics in 2005.

items.title: Cabinet documents from one of Victoria's most influential governments released
items.description: Previously secret cabinet documents from the Labor governments of John Cain Jr and Joan Kirner have been released to the public for the first time.

items.title: Follow the money as 2026's economy asks big questions of all of us
items.description: Australia’s top economists talk interest rate hikes and market movements.

items.title: Quiz: How well prepared are you for what's coming in 2026?
items.description: There's a lot already in the calendar for 2026 in sports, entertainment and politics. Are you ready?

items.title: How a 'silly mistake' cost these men Sydney to Hobart glory
items.description: They should be celebrating a historic win. Instead, the crew of BNC is coming to terms with how a "silly mistake" — their words — cost them the "crown jewel" prize of the Sydney to Hobart overall handicap.

items.title: Ex-Australian cricketer Damien Martyn seriously ill in induced coma
items.description: Former Australian Test and limited overs batsman Damien Martyn is in hospital in Queensland in an induced coma after falling ill this week.

items.title: Five Australians safe after fatal train crash near Machu Picchu
items.description: A head-on collision between two tourist trains near Peru's most famous landmark kills a train driver and injures dozens.

items.title: How running helped Shalom overcome substance abuse
items.description: Shalom Kaa used to think running was something other people did. But after a series of events that left him at his lowest, running became a big part of his recovery following years of substance abuse with crystal methamphetamines.

items.title: Man charged with making threatening phone call to Melbourne journalist
items.description: Investigators from a taskforce targeting crime in the construction industry say a 31-year-old man threatened journalist Nick McKenzie in a Christmas Eve call.

items.title: Man dead and 14yo boy missing after boat capsizes at Sydney beach
items.description: Police confirmed one man has drowned and a 14-year-old boy is missing after their boat capsized at Palm Beach on Sydney's Northern Beaches, with a search and rescue helicopter continuing to search the area.

items.title: 'Disgraceful' acts of looting in bushfire-ravaged community
items.description: After 19 homes were destroyed by bushfire in a picturesque east coast Tasmanian community, residents are now reporting instances of looting — described by the state premier as "disgraceful".

items.title: Female MPs in Japan want more toilets in parliament
items.description: There are just two toilets for women near the main hall in Japan's parliament, with nearly 60 MPs calling for changes to the building to match growing female representation.

items.title: 'I am so happy': Crowd celebrates Thailand's release of Cambodian soldiers
items.description: The release is a key part of a ceasefire deal struck to bring peace to the border between the two countries.

items.title: Crown casino workers announce New Year's Eve strike amid wage row
items.description: About 500 workers at Melbourne's Crown casino will stop work on Wednesday after rejecting a proposal they say will cut pay for new workers and imperil those currently employed.

items.title: Calls for critics to 'grow up' after outcry over period mention on BBC
items.description: Alex Hartley says she was stunned by the reaction to her talking about her period during the BBC's radio commentary of the third Ashes Test.

items.title: Meet the young artists pushing the boundaries of glassmaking
items.description: The art of glassblowing was popularised in a recent reality TV series, but these Australian artists are forging their own paths in the creative process of sculpting this tricky medium.

items.title: How illegitimate regulators operate in the name of a tiny African island
items.description: An ABC investigation has identified several individuals involved in a network of illegitimate corporate regulators and service firms.

items.title: Some Australian Muslims sleeping overnight in mosques after Bondi massacre
items.description: A rise in Islamophobic incidents prompts warnings from Muslim organisations that their communities are at risk of "retribution" and "collective punishment" following the mass shooting.

items.title: 'White Australia' flyer letterbox drop in Newcastle sparks police investigation
items.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns said police would "throw the book" at anyone behind flyers distributed to inner-city Newcastle letterboxes.

items.title: JFK's granddaughter Tatiana Schlossberg dies aged 35
items.description: Tatiana Schlossberg revealed in an essay published in November that she had a rare form of terminal leukaemia.

items.title: Iran's widespread cost-of-living protests reach universities
items.description: Protests over soaring prices and a collapsing currency are spreading across Iran, with students joining shopkeepers in calling on the government to take action.

items.title: Denmark becomes first country in world to end letter delivery
items.description: After 401 years, the Danish postal service has ended letter deliveries as the country fully embraces the digital age.

items.title: Pet owner's warning as dog left 'frothing' after SA beach visit
items.description: Within 20 minutes of leaving an Adelaide beach dogs Lucy and Ella began breathing rapidly and fell "terribly sick", prompting their owner to issue a warning.

items.title: New site lets Queenlanders search online for paedophiles in their area
items.description: Queenslanders can search their local area for reportable sex offenders by providing proof of identification.
